author: sky.cactus
content: Can someone remind me if the frontend will be audited and IPFS hosted?

author: sky.cactus
content: And by audited I mean including all of its dependencies.

author: sky.cactus
content: And the build pipeline (if the build output isn't what is audited).

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is very important that the UI people uses be IPFS hosted, not centrally hosted, because without that I don't think we will have credibility to future people if they cannot look at the code that most people *actually* ran.

author: sky.cactus
content: At the extreme, one can imagine the web host just sending the toxic waste to a central server and saving it instead of deleting it.  If the UI isn't content addressed and fully audited, we cannot verify that didn't happen.

author: bridge-bot

author: sky.cactus
content: Just auditing the frontend is pointless if it isn't content addressable **and** (this is important) most people don't use the content addressed version.

author: sky.cactus
content: If everyone just goes to `https://central-website.ru` and executes "whatever the browser returns", then those people are *effectively* just delegating their participation to whoever controls the `central-website.ru` domain when they went to it.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we have 10,000 people participate in the ceremony but 9900 of them just used `https:/central-website.ru`, then your ceremony only *actually* has 101 participants.

author: sky.cactus
content: Just because the code executes on a user's machine doesn't mean the user is the participant.  If I convince my friend to double click an executable on their machine, I can't then claim that my friend participated because they may have been running some malicious code that I sent them.  They didn't take any steps to verify/validate that they were running the correct code (like using an existing content addressing system built on a P2P network).

author: sky.cactus
content: In fact, I would even go so far as to argue that it is almost pointless to have a centrally hosted version of the page, because those people aren't actually increasing the chances that some toxic waste is burned, nor are they helping prove to future people that some toxic waste was burned.  At best, it is a PR move appealing to those who don't fully understand the point of the process.
